subject: Re: [junit] JUnit Doclet
msgSnippet: ... [snip] ... This is a neat idea.  How do you propose handling asserts where the result can t be expressed as a simple integer?  For instance, the project
messageBody:
On Wed, 2 May 2001 jbirchfield@... wrote:

> All,
> I have started using some code internally and would like to run the
> idea past the JUnit group as a whole. We know the value of performing test
> cases, we just seldom actually take the time to implement them in our
> hectic schedule. So I have put together the frame work for automatically
> generating test cases for any class, any method. Here is a sample Java
> file:
>
> /**
> * @test-method
> * @test-case 4
> * @assert 16
> * @test-case 5
> * @assert 25
> * @test-case 6
> * @assert 36
> */
[snip]

> I have several more ideas for the above, but wanted to share the basics and
> see if anyone was interested in it. This started out as a project to test
> our EJB's(and still does) generating all of the lookup code, and providing
> he method level testing of all our EJB's.
>
> If any interest is generated, I would be more than happy to package up what
> I have so far and share it....
>

This is a neat idea. How do you propose handling asserts where the result
can't be expressed as a simple integer? For instance, the project I'm
working on today has unit tests which compare a UDPDatagram with a reference
I create at runtime using a byte[] array and the UDPDatagram constructor.

--
Joi Ellis Software Engineer
Aravox Technologies joi@..., gyles19@...

No matter what we think of Linux versus FreeBSD, etc., the one thing I
really like about Linux is that it has Microsoft worried. Anything
that kicks a monopoly in the pants has got to be good for something.
- Chris Johnson
